Award.AwardTitle: US Egypt Cooperative Research: Design and Implementation of Experimental High Resolution Imaging Payload System for Nano Satellites
Award.AbstractNarration:
1103969

This project supports a cooperative research project by Dr. Magdy Bayoumi, The Center for Advanced Computer Studies (CACS) at the University of Louisiana at Lafayette, LA and Dr. Amal Zaki, National Authority for Remote Sensing and Space Sciences (NARSS), Cairo, Egypt. They plan to study the Design and Implementation of Experimental High Resolution Imaging Payload System for Nanosatelite. At present, access to Space is limited to some entities; and launching a satellite into orbit is very expensive. Minimizing this cost and making space accessible to scientific and research societies could be reached by design and fabrication of Nano satellite such as the Cubesats. A Cubesat is a type of miniaturized satellite for space research that usually has a volume of exactly of 10cm x10cm x10cm, with a total mass in the order of 1Kg. CubeSat is made from off the shelf components COTS, which is considered as an advantage that makes development much easier, compared to classical satellite development. On the other hand, this limits the final specifications to those of the components available in market. For instance, the final Ground Sample Distance (GSD) is limited by the available commercial imaging systems, which usually do not meet dimensions and resolution requirements simultaneously. A better GSD can be achieved if a costumed optical design is adopted rather than choosing from off the shelf components.

Intellectual Merits: This project will address several challenges that have not been solved efficiently, yet, in designing Micro and Nano satellites, such as limited space, limited performance, and strict requirements of ultra low energy. Solutions to several technical issues will be devices for the first time such as; hardware-software co-design for very low power systems where low power will be the major performance measure. The Technical issues of integrating different technologies; microelectronics, optics, and mechanical will be addressed. Embedded software challenges will be solved. Low power design for UHF/VHF communication systems will be developed which is not straight forward design. The specific application problems of image optics, image sensor, and IP unit will be solved for the imaging payload module. The partners in both institutions have a very strong track record in the proposed field of study. The objectives are clearly stated and are feasible to achieve.

Broader Impacts: The main goal of the collaboration is to focus on the exchange of innovative technologies, which involves design and fabrication of optical, electronics and embedded systems for Nano satellite and space application such as earth observation. This will help both U.S and Egypt in establishing space technology and its applications in our respective institutes. The US team will have an access to an application platform where they can experiment all the novel developed technologies, algorithms, architectures, circuits, and embedded software. The Egyptian team will have an access to the latest research results in optics, microelectronics, UHF/VHF communication systems. Bringing low cost satellite technology to Egypt is a useful effort. There will be training for US and Egyptian students in this international cooperation.

This proposal is supported under the US-Egypt Joint Fund Program where NSF supports the US side and the Government of Egypt funds the Egyptian side.

POR.DRECONTENT:
At present, access to Space is limited to some entities; and launching a satellite into orbit is very expensive. Minimizing this cost and making space accessible to scientific and research societies could be reached by design and fabrication of Nanosatellites. The design of these satellites however faces significance challenges with the multiple size related constraints such as limited space, limited performance, and strict requirements of ultra-low energy.

The cooperative research project led by Dr. Magdy Bayoumi, The Center for Advanced Computer Studies (CACS) at the University of Louisiana at Lafayette, LA and Dr. Amal Zaki, National Authority for Remote Sensing and Space Sciences (NARSS), Cairo, Egypt, addresses two of the most crucial design aspects of a nanosatellite: high resolution imaging and efficient communications. The project goes through the design decisions of the optical, electronic and structural aspect of the imaging payload systems and successfully designs two optical systems that fit size restrictions and image quality requirements along with the appropriate sensors and structural integration.

The implementation of such compact high resolution imaging systems will drastically enhance the capabilities of these low cost and easy to manufacture satellites. Swarms of these satellites can be launched into low earth orbit to perform various surveillance missions. Examples include military surveillance that enhances situational awareness, environmental surveillance that can detects oil leaks or deforestation or disaster monitoring that detects floods or hurricanes and all at the fraction of the cost of larger satellites.

Additionally the project addressed the communication needs of such nanosatellites. The initial project was only concerned with the design of a high resolution imaging payload system. However such high quality images need to be transferred efficiently and having a low power imaging system can be hindered when the transfer process is highly demanding in power. Current nanosatellites links are extremely expensive in power consumption while implemented nanosatellites interlinks are very far from being useful for data transfers. Consequently, the project initiated a second research effort to develop faster, more efficient nanosatellites interlinks that can be useful among future nanosatellites swarm members. With such swarms, dedicated relay satellites can be used to transfer media-sized data efficiently to the ground station while swarm members are free to exchange data with a smaller power overhead.

The project addressed the needs of such links by utilizing optical links as an alternative to RF communication. We presented the component selection and the evaluation steps needed to build such links over several distances. The performance, range and power consumption of these optical links were compared to current popular low power RF technologies and found to be superior over the investigated distances. Furthermore a network topology that can be used with these optical links was introduced.

 

With the development of the high resolution imaging system and the introduction of the optical interlinks the collaborative research project will pave the way to nanosatellites swarms, the next revolution in nanosatellites where all members of the swarm can communicate with each other efficiently and are capable of capturing quality images that fit any surveillance need. Such swarms will have several advantages over larger satellites in terms of flexibility, time to deploy and cost, leading to new era of space technology.
